item.title:
🚨 TRUMP MAY CUT CHINA TARIFFS TO EASE TENSIONS
The Trump administration is weighing major tariff cuts on Chinese imports—possibly by over 50%—to reduce trade tensions, sources say. No final decision has been made, and options remain open.
One idea is a tiered system:
🔸 35% tariffs on non-strategic items
🔸 100%+ tariffs on goods tied to national security
🔸 Phased in over five years
Trump confirmed Tuesday that his 145% tariffs could be reduced but “won’t be zero.” Markets reacted positively to the news.
China responded by signaling openness to talks but warned it won’t negotiate under U.S. threats. Some in Beijing see Trump’s shift as backing down. (From Walter Bloomberg)
item.content:
🚨 TRUMP MAY CUT CHINA TARIFFS TO EASE TENSIONS

The Trump administration is weighing major tariff cuts on Chinese imports—possibly by over 50%—to reduce trade tensions, sources say. No final decision has been made, and options remain open.

One idea is a tiered system:

🔸 35% tariffs on non-strategic items

🔸 100%+ tariffs on goods tied to national security

🔸 Phased in over five years

Trump confirmed Tuesday that his 145% tariffs could be reduced but “won’t be zero.” Markets reacted positively to the news.

China responded by signaling openness to talks but warned it won’t negotiate under U.S. threats. Some in Beijing see Trump’s shift as backing down.
item.contentSnippet:
🚨 TRUMP MAY CUT CHINA TARIFFS TO EASE TENSIONS
The Trump administration is weighing major tariff cuts on Chinese imports—possibly by over 50%—to reduce trade tensions, sources say. No final decision has been made, and options remain open.
One idea is a tiered system:
🔸 35% tariffs on non-strategic items
🔸 100%+ tariffs on goods tied to national security
🔸 Phased in over five years
Trump confirmed Tuesday that his 145% tariffs could be reduced but “won’t be zero.” Markets reacted positively to the news.
China responded by signaling openness to talks but warned it won’t negotiate under U.S. threats. Some in Beijing see Trump’s shift as backing down.

Days ago, it was reported that the U.S. and Vietnam were close to a deal. (From TKL)

item.title:
Keep watching the U.S. Dollar:
As the S&P 500 rises +5% in 2 days on “tariff de-escalation” headlines, the U.S. Dollar Index, $DXY, is up a mere 0.2% today.
The U.S. Dollar is just about the only asset not buying these headlines today.
Furthermore, the U.S. Dollar has been a key leading indicator of trade war sentiment.
It’s almost as though the U.S. Dollar thinks U.S. trade headlines have lost credibility.
Something is off. (From TKL)
item.content:
Keep watching the U.S. Dollar:

As the S&P 500 rises +5% in 2 days on “tariff de-escalation” headlines, the U.S. Dollar Index, $DXY, is up a mere 0.2% today.

The U.S. Dollar is just about the only asset not buying these headlines today.

Furthermore, the U.S. Dollar has been a key leading indicator of trade war sentiment.

It’s almost as though the U.S. Dollar thinks U.S. trade headlines have lost credibility.

Something is off.
item.contentSnippet:
Keep watching the U.S. Dollar: $DXY, is up a mere 0.2% today.
The U.S. Dollar is just about the only asset not buying these headlines today.
Furthermore, the U.S. Dollar has been a key leading indicator of trade war sentiment.
It’s almost as though the U.S. Dollar thinks U.S. trade headlines have lost credibility.
Something is off.

item.title:
Retail investors were just cheated:
Yesterday at 12:00 PM ET, US Treasury Secretary Bessent said he sees "de-escalation with China" and the current situation is "unsustainable."
These comments were provided at a CLOSED-DOOR investor summit hosted by JP Morgan.
This summit was not open to the public or to the media.
Then, at 5:18 PM ET, President Trump said tariffs on China "will not be as high as 145%."
Bessent effectively told a closed-group of Wall Street investors that de-escalation with China was coming BEFORE the public knew.
The result was a move of +5% in S&P 500 futures, for a total of +$2.2 TRILLION of market cap.
Investors at the JP Morgan event were able to front-run these headlines.
How is this fair for retail investors? (From TKL)
item.content:
Retail investors were just cheated:

Yesterday at 12:00 PM ET, US Treasury Secretary Bessent said he sees "de-escalation with China" and the current situation is "unsustainable."

These comments were provided at a CLOSED-DOOR investor summit hosted by JP Morgan.

This summit was not open to the public or to the media.

Then, at 5:18 PM ET, President Trump said tariffs on China "will not be as high as 145%."

Bessent effectively told a closed-group of Wall Street investors that de-escalation with China was coming BEFORE the public knew.

The result was a move of +5% in S&P 500 futures, for a total of +$2.2 TRILLION of market cap.

Investors at the JP Morgan event were able to front-run these headlines.

How is this fair for retail investors?
item.contentSnippet:
Retail investors were just cheated:
Yesterday at 12:00 PM ET, US Treasury Secretary Bessent said he sees "de-escalation with China" and the current situation is "unsustainable."
These comments were provided at a CLOSED-DOOR investor summit hosted by JP Morgan.
This summit was not open to the public or to the media.
Then, at 5:18 PM ET, President Trump said tariffs on China "will not be as high as 145%."
Bessent effectively told a closed-group of Wall Street investors that de-escalation with China was coming BEFORE the public knew.
The result was a move of +5% in S&P 500 futures, for a total of +$2.2 TRILLION of market cap.
Investors at the JP Morgan event were able to front-run these headlines.
How is this fair for retail investors?

Follow us @KobeissiLetter for real time analysis as this develops. (From TKL)
item.content:

Trump is now claiming that tariffs on China will come down from 145%.

It seems like tariffs are set to come down and Powell is staying (for now).

item.title:
Something doesn't add up here:
1. Trump on April 7th: Fed Chair Powell is "slow moving"
2. Bessent on April 14th: Trump Admin is thinking of successor to Powell
3. Trump on April 17th: Fed Chair Powell "will be out of there"
4. Trump on April 19th: "Studying" if he can fire Fed Chair Powell
5. Trump on April 21st: Fed Chair Powell is "a major loser"
6. Trump today: "No intention" to fire Fed Chair Powell
What changed today? (From TKL)
item.content:
Something doesn't add up here:

1. Trump on April 7th: Fed Chair Powell is "slow moving"

2. Bessent on April 14th: Trump Admin is thinking of successor to Powell

3. Trump on April 17th: Fed Chair Powell "will be out of there"

4. Trump on April 19th: "Studying" if he can fire Fed Chair Powell

5. Trump on April 21st: Fed Chair Powell is "a major loser"

6. Trump today: "No intention" to fire Fed Chair Powell

What changed today?
item.contentSnippet:
Something doesn't add up here:
1. Trump on April 7th: Fed Chair Powell is "slow moving"
2. Bessent on April 14th: Trump Admin is thinking of successor to Powell
3. Trump on April 17th: Fed Chair Powell "will be out of there"
4. Trump on April 19th: "Studying" if he can fire Fed Chair Powell
5. Trump on April 21st: Fed Chair Powell is "a major loser"
6. Trump today: "No intention" to fire Fed Chair Powell
What changed today?

item.content:

item.title:
RT by @EconomyApp: $TSLA Tesla Q1 FY25:
• Revenue -9% Y/Y to $19.3B ($2.1B miss). • Gross margin 16% (-1pp Y/Y). • Operating margin 2% (-3pp Y/Y). • Capex -46% Y/Y to $1.5B. • Free cash flow $0.6B. • Non-GAAP EPS $0.27 ($0.15 miss). (From App Economy Insights)
item.content:
$TSLA Tesla Q1 FY25:

• Revenue -9% Y/Y to $19.3B ($2.1B miss).
• Gross margin 16% (-1pp Y/Y).
• Operating margin 2% (-3pp Y/Y).
• Capex -46% Y/Y to $1.5B.
• Free cash flow $0.6B.
• Non-GAAP EPS $0.27 ($0.15 miss).
item.contentSnippet:
$TSLA Tesla Q1 FY25:
• Revenue -9% Y/Y to $19.3B ($2.1B miss). • Gross margin 16% (-1pp Y/Y). • Operating margin 2% (-3pp Y/Y). • Capex -46% Y/Y to $1.5B. • Free cash flow $0.6B. • Non-GAAP EPS $0.27 ($0.15 miss).

R to @nickgerli1: 6) No one else in the housing market is really talking about Manhattan.
But I think it could be poised for a big rebound soon.
The market is the cheapest it's been in decades relative to income and rent.
Suggesting a turnaround could be in the offering. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
6) No one else in the housing market is really talking about Manhattan.

But I think it could be poised for a big rebound soon.

The market is the cheapest it's been in decades relative to income and rent.

Suggesting a turnaround could be in the offering.

6) No one else in the housing market is really talking about Manhattan.
But I think it could be poised for a big rebound soon.
The market is the cheapest it's been in decades relative to income and rent.
Suggesting a turnaround could be in the offering.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 5) But you can see that today, Manhattan's "fair value" relative to income has now surpassed its actual value.
Creating an undervalued market. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
5) But you can see that today, Manhattan's "fair value" relative to income has now surpassed its actual value.

Creating an undervalued market.
item.contentSnippet:
5) But you can see that today, Manhattan's "fair value" relative to income has now surpassed its actual value.
Creating an undervalued market.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 4) Today's nominal price in Manhattan is about the same as it was in 2014.
And barely above where it was in 2006.
Evidence that this housing market has been on the struggle bus for a while. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
4) Today's nominal price in Manhattan is about the same as it was in 2014.

And barely above where it was in 2006.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 3) The reason is that home values actually corrected in Manhattan by around 20% from the peak in mid-2022.
Moreover, Manhattan's housing market was also struggling prior to the pandemic.
So in terms of relative affordability, it has gained significantly. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
3) The reason is that home values actually corrected in Manhattan by around 20% from the peak in mid-2022.

Moreover, Manhattan's housing market was also struggling prior to the pandemic.

So in terms of relative affordability, it has gained significantly.

item.title:

The question is: how is it priced compared to its long-term norms?
And unquestionably, New York is the cheapest it's been to buy in decades. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
2) But New York has and always will be expensive.

The question is: how is it priced compared to its long-term norms?

And unquestionably, New York is the cheapest it's been to buy in decades.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 1) Of course, Manhattan is still very expensive.
It's the 8th most expensive county in America, and the only one located outside California.
Typical home/condo value of $1.1 million. With associated mortgage payment of $7,500/month to buy. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
1) Of course, Manhattan is still very expensive.

item.title:
Typical home (condo/co-op) value in Manhattan today is $1.1 million.
Typical apartment rent is $5,091/month, or $61,000 per year.
The resulting home value/rent ratio in Manhattan is 18.5, the lowest it's been in 20+ years.
Indicating Manhattan might actually be a good place to buy right now. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:

Typical apartment rent is $5,091/month, or $61,000 per year.

The resulting home value/rent ratio in Manhattan is 18.5, the lowest it's been in 20+ years.

Indicating Manhattan might actually be a good place to buy right now.

Typical apartment rent is $5,091/month, or $61,000 per year.
The resulting home value/rent ratio in Manhattan is 18.5, the lowest it's been in 20+ years.
Indicating Manhattan might actually be a good place to buy right now.

item.title:
RT by @SchwabResearch: Today on The Big Picture on Market On Close:
— @LizAnnSonders says that "any move by the Fed to preemptively start easing policy aggressively ... might not have the intended effect of boosting growth or boosting confidence."
— Cooper Howard tells @Cline_Woods that "the market is concerned about the independence of the Fed."
— Plus, tracking the likelihood of a recession. (From SchwabR)
item.content:
Today on The Big Picture on Market On Close:

— @LizAnnSonders says that "any move by the Fed to preemptively start easing policy aggressively ... might not have the intended effect of boosting growth or boosting confidence."

— Cooper Howard tells @Cline_Woods that "the market is concerned about the independence of the Fed."

— Plus, tracking the likelihood of a recession.

item.title: R to @nickgerli1: 6) I will be likely buying real estate in Austin by the end of this year, as I feel confident this market has good long-term prospects and will have the right affordability and valuation metrics by year-end. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content: 6) I will be likely buying real estate in Austin by the end of this year, as I feel confident this market has good long-term prospects and will have the right affordability and valuation metrics by year-end.
item.contentSnippet: 6) I will be likely buying real estate in Austin by the end of this year, as I feel confident this market has good long-term prospects and will have the right affordability and valuation metrics by year-end.

item.title: R to @nickgerli1: 5) But I think the fundamentals of Austin are solid. The area's population growth is top of the table. And now prices/rents are cheap enough to allow that growth to continue into the future (after a brief hangover after the pandemic). (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content: 5) But I think the fundamentals of Austin are solid. The area's population growth is top of the table. And now prices/rents are cheap enough to allow that growth to continue into the future (after a brief hangover after the pandemic).
item.contentSnippet: 5) But I think the fundamentals of Austin are solid. The area's population growth is top of the table. And now prices/rents are cheap enough to allow that growth to continue into the future (after a brief hangover after the pandemic).

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 4) Austin's rental market suggests prices are a bit more overvalued.
The Home Price / Rent Ratio is currently 17.6.
While the long-run average is 15.2. Suggesting 15% overvaluation. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
4) Austin's rental market suggests prices are a bit more overvalued.

The Home Price / Rent Ratio is currently 17.6.

While the long-run average is 15.2. Suggesting 15% overvaluation.
item.contentSnippet:
4) Austin's rental market suggests prices are a bit more overvalued.
The Home Price / Rent Ratio is currently 17.6.
While the long-run average is 15.2. Suggesting 15% overvaluation.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 3) Prior to pandemic, in 2019, prices in Austin traded for 4.0x income.
The typical value was $313k and the median income was $78k.
In order to understand home prices, you have to understand it's all relative. Income is the main input that matters, along with rent. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
3) Prior to pandemic, in 2019, prices in Austin traded for 4.0x income.

The typical value was $313k and the median income was $78k.

In order to understand home prices, you have to understand it's all relative. Income is the main input that matters, along with rent.
item.contentSnippet:
3) Prior to pandemic, in 2019, prices in Austin traded for 4.0x income.
The typical value was $313k and the median income was $78k.
In order to understand home prices, you have to understand it's all relative. Income is the main input that matters, along with rent.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 2) To understand this point clearer: the typical home value in Austin is $449k right now. Which is 4.4x the area's median income.
This 4.4x Home Value/Income Ratio is now almost back down to the long-term, 20 -year average.
Which is how you know Austin will soon be a "buy". (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
2) To understand this point clearer: the typical home value in Austin is $449k right now. Which is 4.4x the area's median income.

This 4.4x Home Value/Income Ratio is now almost back down to the long-term, 20 -year average.

Which is how you know Austin will soon be a "buy".
item.contentSnippet:
2) To understand this point clearer: the typical home value in Austin is $449k right now. Which is 4.4x the area's median income.
This 4.4x Home Value/Income Ratio is now almost back down to the long-term, 20 -year average.
Which is how you know Austin will soon be a "buy".

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 1) The way Austin has become more fairly valued is through two mechanisms.
First - prices have dropped 20.4% from their peak in 2022. Returning affordability.
Second - the median income in the metro has continued rising, and is now up to $102,000, increasing relative affordability. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
1) The way Austin has become more fairly valued is through two mechanisms.

First - prices have dropped 20.4% from their peak in 2022. Returning affordability.

Second - the median income in the metro has continued rising, and is now up to $102,000, increasing relative affordability.
item.contentSnippet:
1) The way Austin has become more fairly valued is through two mechanisms.
First - prices have dropped 20.4% from their peak in 2022. Returning affordability.
Second - the median income in the metro has continued rising, and is now up to $102,000, increasing relative affordability.

item.title:
The first market to bottom in this housing downturn will be Austin, TX.
Prices are already down 20% from peak.
And the market has shifted from being 46% overvalued to now only 8% overvalued.
Buy the end of this year, Austin will be a "buy". (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
